item.title: An Insider's View of the Texas Measles Outbreak
item.description: Katherine Wells, the public health director in Lubbock, Texas, describes her fight to stop the largest measles outbreak since 2000, despite a chaotic reorganization of federal health agencies.

item.title: What it was like inside St. Peter's Square when the new pope was announced
item.description: As Cardinal Robert Prevost's name was announced, a sound of shock rose up. It was something few people had anticipated — the new pope is from the United States.

item.title: Trump's gutting of AmeriCorps hits hard, for both volunteers and communities
item.description: The Trump administration slashed funding for the national service agency and fired most of its staff. 32,000 people, mostly young adults, were forced to stop work immediately.

item.title: Court rules Alabama redistricting intentionally discriminates against Black voters
item.description: A federal court says Alabama can't use a congressional map it found unconstitutional. The ruling comes in a voting rights case that resulted in the state getting a second Black member of Congress.

item.title: Why Warren Buffett matters beyond Wall Street
item.description: The 94-year-old investor is retiring as Berkshire Hathaway's CEO. He's built both a fortune and a reputation as "the nicest billionaire" — at a time when many other billionaires are widely criticized.
